abstract.p: US Housing and Urban Development Department and US Environmental Protection Agency open new Web site that offers access to government maps and documents pinpointing environmental problems and information about communities across country (S)

block.p: Prospective home buyers -- or anyone concerned about a neighborhood -- can now gain access through the Internet to government maps and documents pinpointing environmental problems and offering information about communities across the country.

The free service, which began last Tuesday and was immediately overwhelmed by demand, is a joint project of two federal agencies, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Environmental Protection Agency.

Prospective home buyers -- or anyone concerned about a neighborhood -- can now gain access through the Internet to government maps and documents pinpointing environmental problems and offering information about communities across the country.

The free service, which began last Tuesday and was immediately overwhelmed by demand, is a joint project of two federal agencies, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Environmental Protection Agency.

The first thing visitors to the Web site for the maps found last week was a box headlined ''Our Apologies,'' saying that the site had been experiencing delays and redirecting visitors to a similar map site maintained by the environmental agency. ''Within the first four hours we got 10,000 requests for maps,'' said Lee Jones, a spokesman for the housing department. ''It's up and running, but we plan to put a superserver in place within two weeks so that nobody has to wait.''

Dick Burk, the associate secretary of Housing and Urban Development who led the team that created what the department calls HUD E-Maps, said environmental data can be found ''for every ZIP Code, every neighborhood.'' The Web site, www.hud.gov/emaps, has maps showing toxic release sites, brownfield sites, waste-handling sites, industrial plants, waste-water treatment plants and federal Superfund cleanup sites.
